lines.text: Hey, are you getting sick?
I don't know. How do girls usually act when you kiss them?
Well, they don't turn green.
Then I'm sick. Get me out of here.
I never saw anybody like you, you never have any clothes on.
Well if anyone heard you complaining about it they would put you in a psychopathic ward.

[comparing his gun to Dr. Lorenz's]
Mine's bigger than yours.
We were discussing Philippine economics when we were so rudely interrupted.
My own field! Miss Marlowe was kind enough to listen to me.
They're going to be free in 1946, aren't they?
They are - provided America does not insist on fighting a war with Japan. It's my opinion that that contingency is going to keep the Philippines from being free.
Won't Japan gobble them up?
No offense, but Japan or Canada or anybody else can have the Philippines as far as I'm concerned. It's hot in Manila!
Might even be hotter before long.
Hot enough to go around in shorts?
Ah, there's a Canadian for you! Let them take their clothes off, and they're happy.
How are you doing, angel?
I think I got pushed in the face by someone. My - My lipstick's smeared.
Aww, you look cute.
And now, if you'll excuse me, I'll go to my cabin... and faint.
I'm not so obsessed with money as you seem to be. I can do without it.
You stick around with me and you'll get plenty of practice.
How can you come from Medicine Hat?
There's nothing wrong with Medicine Hat! It's hot in the summer, cold in the winter and nothing ever happens there!
You certainly are a girl of many colors. First, your legs get blue. Then, your face turns green. And, now, your red all over.
I never knew what suffering was until I came on this pleasure trip.

[Talking about Japanese people in general]
You are always so calm. You never show anything.

We are told not to. It is our way of rife. We must not show too much sad-i-ness or too much joy. If you praise what we have, we say it is nus-sing. If you admire our sons, we must say thay are unworthy.
It'll probably end up with Captain Higoto marrying us on the boat.
Oh, no! I want a church wedding and a groom who's got more than two suits.
Don't be an innocent bystander; they always get hurt.

[after they kiss]
What's the matter?
Look, I didn't mean that.
I did. Why didn't you?
Well, a fellow with a suit like mine, shouldn't go around kissing girls.
If you catch pneumonia, what will happen to our romance?
What will happen to it anyway, if you don't shave.

[to Lorenz as they both view U.S. planes overhead]
Any of your friends in Tokyo have trouble committing hari-kiri, those boys'd be glad to help them out.
Pull up a chair, Joe. Thanks, I will. What's that you're knocking yourselves out with? Hey, waiter, I'll have one of those. Well, how we doing?
Mr. Leland, I believe that a man should tell the woman he's going to marry everything.
Oh, in that case, I'll come clean.
What?
I look old, but that's because I've worried a lot. Actually, I haven't yet reached the age of legal consent, and if you don't get out of here, I'm gonna yell for help.
All right, you can get yourself another heiress.
I guess nobody ever really knows anybody.

[Clears throat]
We're going to know each other eventually, so, why not now.
That seems reasonable enough. I'm Alberta Marlow.
My name's Rick Leland. Would you mind stepping into the light? Please.
[Both walk towards the light]
On a Jap freighter, too. You better pinch me.
I don't think I know you that well.
A pretty girl on a boat and no college boy, no handsome officers, no eligible men of any description. That's wonderful.
Are your legs always blue?
They're not blue.
Oh, Sugi, get me that blanket.
I don't want a blanket. I want the sunshine.
Oh, your teeth are chattering like a crap game. This is November and it's winter sunshine.
Where will you stay in Panama, Mr. Leland?
The Pan American. It's very quite and respectable.
That ain't for me.
Where are you going beautiful?
I'll have to find some place where they have the bath at the end of the hall and a 40 cents lunch.
I know the guy who owns the Pan American. He'll give you a rate.
Everybody has bad luck with me. Goodbye.
Sam, you can help me. People tell you things.
People tell me because I don't tell. I tell, they don't tell me any more.
I'm sorry to be late, angel. I was held up.
Oh, I like waiting for you Ricky. Wouldn't I make a splendid wife.
What'll it be?
Something cool and long.
You can sit down, now, folks. Nobodies going anywhere.
You guys been lookin' for a war, haven't you?
That's right, Rick. That's why we're starting it.
You may start it, Joe. But, we'll finish it.
When you're slapped, you're gonna take it and like it.
What was that boat you were talking about?
The Genoa Maru, sailing tonight for Yokohama, by way of New York, the Panama Canal, and Honolulu.
It's for me.
Excuse, please.
How much?
To port of final destination, 212 dollars 80 cents.
You probably don't share my enthusiasm for the Japanese.
I don't know, I never thought much about them.
A wonderful little people. Wonderful. Greatly misunderstood, believe me. To know them, that is to really know them, is to feel the deepest affection for them.
Who are you after? Are you a G-man or something?
What if I was?
I just wondered.
Powder, angel. Now, when you go, stop thinking and keep your mouth shut.
At last, we're alone. Now, listen, bright eyes.
No romance. There's something very interesting over there, Ricky.
Where? What do you mean?
T. Oki. It's not the same Oki that came down from Halifax with us. That's another man.
Ah, the heat's kidding you angel. They all look alike.
No they don't either. Not if you examine them closely.
One night, you told me about your troubles in the Army. I'd like to hear more about that.
I got in a jam with a dame.
Yes?
I needed some dough. I had access to the regimental funds so I borrowed it, intending to put it back, of course.
Of course.
They found out first. The brass hats could have given me a chance if they wanted to, but they didn't. They tied me up with pink ribbons and threw me to the wolves. Write your own finish.
What's the matter you, Rick?
What's a matter you? What's a matter me, Sam?
All the time, people say you no good. Big smell from up north. I what's a matter you come back? Too much Army here. Everyone know. You through with Panama. Panama through with you!
Well, Sam, maybe I won't be here long.
You no need money? Sam smell big fish.
Sam keep nose clean. Sam no smell fish. No catchy trouble.
All the time, you like trouble. Maybe so, Dr. Lorenz trouble?
Maybe so.
Gal too?
I don't know Sam. I hope she's all right.
She got your bad. Much trouble. All the time, much trouble.
Maybe you overlooked something?
Could you suggest anything, sir, that we might have overlooked?
What about your getaway?
We have a rendezvous with an undersea boat.
